Nice work, Peter, it's a very nice demonstration.  I also saw the
humanoid =
shuffle backwards.  It does seem easier to do that than go
forwards.  

My =
guess is that the behavior characterization of final (x,y,z)
probably confl=
ates too many behaviors.  The trick in walking is in
oscillation, so the pr=
oper stepping stone needs to have some ability
to oscillate, regardless of =
where its head ends up.  I'd also guess
that the substrate also could be si=
mplified.  I believe that it is
allowing so much recurrence that it is very=
 difficult to produce a
stable system.

You know what would be cool is if y=
ou could specify the behavior
characterization yourself as the user, like i=
f the program provided
all the possible state variables and you could selec=
t what to include
in the characterization.

ken

--- In neat@...=
m, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@...>
wrote:
>
> Hey I am glad that =
you like that stuff, it was around in my computer 
> a whole week but I dec=
ided to upload a binary just before a day. Let 
> me explain the details be=
hind it. As you are probably familiar with 
> the other NEVH shit this code=
 does the same but uses another NEAT 
> implememtation and novelty search. =
(steady state evolution). 
> I've seen some dolls actually walking, but bac=
kwards. Kind of weird. 
> I guess it is the easier way, though :) 
> The be=
havior characterization is (as Peter B proposed) the final XYZ 
> location =
of the head. The distance is simply the eucldian distance 
> between those =
points. I agree that there are many options and I am 
> trying out many dif=
ferent BCs (behavior characterizations). But this 
> one works well. 
> The=
 nodes in the substrate are arranged in a geometric way to reflect 
> the b=
ody's geometry in space. Each output corresponds to a joint 
> angle. Arms =
and legs are placed symmetrically in the left and right 
> sides. The head =
(neck joint) is placed above them in the center. 
> Outputs are drawn in gr=
een. Inputs (head velocity) are drawn in red. 
> Hidden nodes are drawn in =
yellow. Ergh I see it is upside-down but 
> HyperNEAT doesn't care about th=
is anyway :) 
> The 5th input to the CPPN is the distance from 0, 0 in node=
-specific 
> data and the distance between the 2 points when computing the =
weight 
> of the connection between 2 nodes. Just like in your paper, the s=
ame 
> bias. 
> 
> Peter
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "David D'Ambrosi=
o" <ddambro84@> wrote:
> >
> > Wow, this looks really cool Petar.  I though=
t it would be awhile
> > before we saw HyperNEAT and novelty search combine=
d.  I ran it 
> while I
> > was working on other stuff for a bit over 50,00=
0 evaluations, 
> checking
> > in on it periodically.  The behavioral diver=
sity was really
> > impressive: I got guys that were taking baby steps and =
guys that 
> were
> > doing yoga poses (I swear one of them did "the chair"=
), although 
> there
> > were still a good number of repeats, especially ne=
ar the end 
> (falling
> > onto theirs knees seemed pretty common).  No one=
 that I saw had a 
> good
> > walking gait, but I guess it's possible that =
one could have when I
> > wasn't watching, perhaps we need an option to bro=
wse the archive. 
> I'm
> > curious about a few things, if you wouldn't min=
d sharing:
> > 
> > -What did you use as a novelty metric?  It's seems like=
 there are a
> > number of viable options here.
> > 
> > -What do the nodes=
 on the substrate mean, and are they just on a 
> flat
> > plane?  I used y=
our older version when it was first released, and 
> if I
> > remember righ=
t the two on the left are inputs and the stuff on the
> > right is various =
joints, but I wanted to make sure.
> > 
> > -Similarly, what do you use as =
the 5th input on the CPPN?
> > 
> > Thanks,
> > David D'Ambrosio
